title: Luis Eyzaguirre
text:
Luis Armando Eyzaguirre Silva (born 22 June 1939 in <a href="Santiago%2C%20Chile">Santiago, Chile</a>), also known as Fifo, is a former <a href="Chile">Chile</a>an football player. He played <a href="right%20back">right back</a> in the <a href="Universidad%20de%20Chile%20%28football%20club%29">Universidad de Chile</a> football team known as the "<a href="Ballet%20Azul">Ballet Azul</a>", with which he won five national championships.
He played in <a href="1959%20South%20American%20Championship%20%28Argentina%29">1959 Copa América</a> and in the <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> he achieved third place with the <a href="Chile%20national%20football%20team">Chilean national selection</a> for the <a href="1962%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1962 FIFA World Cup</a> and was one of the players involved in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Santiago%20%281962%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%29">Battle of Santiago</a> incident during the Group 2 match between Chile and Italy. He played one match in the <a href="1966%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1966 FIFA World Cup</a>. He was considered one of the best <a href="right%20back">right back</a> of his time, next to the Brazilian <a href="Djalma%20Santos">Djalma Santos</a>. He played 39 matches for his country between 1959 and 1966. He was one of the players invited by <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a> to play in <a href="1963%20England%20v%20Rest%20of%20the%20World%20football%20match">a commemorative game</a> celebrating the centennial anniversary of <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a>.
